At-a-Glance: Add the right space at the right time. Manage frame count, drawn comb, and queen excluders to hit flow peaks without swarming.
Why it Matters: Improves honey moisture and capping quality.
Objectives: Define supering triggers from weight/forage cues.
Stage drawn comb ahead of flows; manage excluders wisely.
Align extraction windows with moisture targets.
What Good Looks Like: Decision card: add super at weight delta or bloom cue.
Drawn comb topmost; wet supers returned post-extraction to clean up.
Excluder used when needed; not hindering early build.
Step-by-Step: 1) Watch scales and bloom; trigger supering at agreed thresholds.
2) Place drawn comb above; foundation framed between drawn when needed.
3) Manage excluder: on for harvest purity; remove if impeding build.
4) Pull when mostly capped or moisture OK; return wet supers to clean.
Seasonality & Climate: Cold springs slow draw—delay heavy foundation-only supers.
Heat waves raise moisture risk—improve ventilation.
Data & Thresholds: Daily weight gain trigger (e.g., +1–2 kg/day sustained).
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Backfilling brood -> Add space now; relieve with drawn comb.
Symptom: Bridge comb mess -> Re-space; ensure frames tight; level hives.
Symptom: High moisture -> Delay pull; dry room; improve ventilation.
Common Pitfalls: Adding too late or with only foundation during flow.
Tools & Techniques: Hive scales, refractometer, bee escapes, triangle boards.
Safety & Compliance: Safe lifting and carrying; team lifts for heavy supers.
Communications: Explain timing logic so helpers act consistently.
Notes: Keep 1–2 spare supers per hive in peak season—prevents panic.
